author: BFMTV
title: En Russie, deux poètes lourdement condamnés pour un texte hostile à l'offensive en Ukraine
text:
RFI En Russie, deux poètes lourdement condamnés pour un texte hostile à l'offensive en Ukraine Lire l'article complet RFI 29 décembre 2023 à 1:50 AM
Jusqu'à sept ans de prison pour des mots. Ce jeudi 28 décembre, un tribunal de Moscou a condamné deux hommes à de lourdes peines pour avoir récité des vers contre l'offensive ukrainienne lors d'une manifestation l'année dernière.
La répression des voix dissidentes en Russie ne faiblit pas en cette fin d’année. Selon l'ONG russe OVD-Info, près de 20 000 Russes ont été arrêtés depuis le début du conflit en Ukraine pour avoir protesté contre la politique du Kremlin. L’ONG Memorial recense 633 prisonniers politiques derrière les barreaux.
Dernières victimes en date : deux poètes russes qui ont participé à une lecture contre la guerre en Ukraine, condamnés par un tribunal de Moscou à des peines de cinq ans et demi et sept ans de prison. Les deux hommes ont été condamnés pour incitation à la haine envers les membres des groupes armés du Donbass et pour « appels publics à commettre des activités contre la sécurité de l'État ». Leur tort ? Avoir participé à une lecture publique de poèmes à Moscou, près de la statue du poète Maïakovski, lieu traditionnel de rassemblement d’opposants au pouvoir et de dissidents depuis l'époque soviétique.
L'un d'eux affirme avoir été violé pendant son arrestation Lors cet événement, Artyom Kamardin, 33 ans, qui écope de la peine la plus lourde, avait récité un poème hostile aux séparatistes pro-russes de l'est de l'Ukraine. Comme Yegor Shtovba, 23 ans, qui écope de 5 ans et demi, il avait été interpellé en septembre 2022, au lendemain de la lecture publique.
Lire la suite sur RFI
TENDANCE Russie: des personnalités participent à une fête "presque nues" et suscitent l'indignation BFMTV Gérard Depardieu doit être considéré comme "un malade", Marlène Jobert sort du silence Purepeople Victoria Abril accusée d'agressions sexuelles par Lucie Lucas : un acteur de Clem la défend, "elle est assurée de mon soutien inconditionnel" Purebreak Nicolas Sarkozy et Carla Bruni : Leur sublime château au coeur d'une sombre affaire, un procureur de la République saisi Purepeople "J'ai été témoin..." : Lucie Lucas fait de nouvelles révélations après ses accusations contre Victoria Abril Purebreak

title: Cold wave alert in three districts of state till Dec 15 - Times of India
text: Ranchi: Ranchi met centre on Friday kept up its cold wave alert as several parts of the state witnessed temperatures below normal for the second consecutive day. Cold wave alerts were issued for Bokaro, Dhanbad, and Ramgarh districts for the next two days.The IMD has also forecast predominantly clear skies for the rest of Jharkhand over the next five days, along with early morning mist or fog. Ranchi's minimum temperatures are expected to range between 9 degrees Celsius and 11 degrees Celsius, with maximum temperatures hovering around 23 degrees Celsius to 24 degrees Celsius. North-east Jharkhand, including Godda and Pakur, may see slightly warmer days, with maximum temperatures reaching up to 26 degrees Celsius.\"The cold wave conditions are due to the prevailing north-westerly winds over Jharkhand, leading to a significant drop in minimum temperatures in affected regions,\" Ranchi met centre's director- in-charge Abhishek Anand said.The IMD has advised residents, especially vulnerable groups such as the elderly and children, to avoid prolonged exposure to low temperatures and remain indoors during night-time. Farmers are also encouraged to adopt protective measures to shield crops from the cold.In its evening weather bulletin, IMD said that the night-time temperature in Ranchi hovered at 9 degrees Celsius. Dhanbad recorded a night-time temperature of 11 degrees Celsius while Daltonganj recorded 7.9 degrees Celsius and Bokaro recorded 8.1 degrees Celsius.Akshay Kumar, a resident of Ramgarh, said, \"The cold is biting, and mornings have been challenging, especially for those travelling early. We rely heavily on warm layers and hot beverages to cope with the chilly weather.\"

author: ABCNews
title: 'Facilitating terrorism': Crypto exchange Binance sued by Hamas hostages, Oct. 7 victims' families
text: An American woman freed after being held [hostage](https://abc7chicago.com/tag/hostage/) in Gaza and the families of two men killed in the Oct. 7 attack in Israel sued Binance, the leading cryptocurrency exchange, which they accused of providing a funding mechanism for Hamas. The lawsuit, filed in Manhattan federal court Thursday, also named Iran and Syria and is the first of what could be a torrent of lawsuits over the Hamas attack against Israel that left at least 1,200 Israelis dead, according to Israeli officials. Among the plaintiffs are members of the Raanan family. Judith Raanan and her daughter, Natalie, were kidnapped and held in Gaza before they were freed in a prisoner exchange in October. Other plaintiffs include the family and estate of Itay Glisko, the 20-year-old New Jersey native and IDF sergeant killed in action during the attack by Hamas. MORE | [Family of American hostages freed by Hamas speak out: 'It is not the end'](https://abc7chicago.com/judith-raanan-natalie-israel-hamas/13958264/) The lawsuit accused Binance of processing numerous transactions for Hamas between 2017 and 2023, "providing a clandestine financing tool that Binance deliberately hid from U.S. regulators." Binance did not immediately respond to ABC News' request for comment. The company and its former CEO Chengpeng Zhao pled guilty last year to violations of U.S. anti-money laundering laws while agreeing to pay more than $4 billion in fines. The violations included processing and failing to report "transactions with cryptocurrency wallets that Binance senior executives had knowledge were linked to terrorist groups such as Hamas or Palestine Islamic Jihad," according to a Department of Justice filing. MORE | [24 hostages released from Gaza, 39 Palestinian prisoners swapped after temporary ceasefire deal](https://abc7chicago.com/what-time-will-the-hostages-be-released-ceasefire-israel-hamas/14099356/) Zhao agreed to resign as part of his plea deal and will be sentenced in February where he faces up to 18 months in prison. The company also agreed to enter in a number of anti-money laundering and sanctions compliance programs and retain an independent monitor for the next three years. "For years, Binance remained willfully blind to the use of its platform by illicit actors, including terrorists, by failing to do any due diligence on the vast majority of its users prior to August 2021," the lawsuit said. The lawsuit added, "Incredibly, Binance went out of its way to protect users associated with Hamas and other terrorist groups from regulatory scrutiny, especially if they were 'VIP users who generated huge profits for Binance." MORE | [Families of hostages held in Gaza storm Israel's parliament meeting demanding deal for release](https://abc7chicago.com/israel-hostages-parliament-hamas/14349885/) The lawsuit, modeled on suits that emerged after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, accused Binance of aiding terror organizations, providing material support to terrorists and sought unspecified damages. "This needs to be done. These crypto funds are turning a blind eye to all of this illegal activity and now it's actually facilitating terrorism," said plaintiff's attorney Rob Seiden. "We're doing this to send a message to these crypto institutions: you can't do this stuff. You have to be more vigilant." More than 100 hostages are thought to still be detained in Gaza, according to Israeli officials. Israel's military response to the Oct. 7 attack has killed at least 27,019 people in the Gaza Strip, according to Gaza's Hamas-controlled Ministry of Health.

author: @Le360_Afrique
title: Algérie: les conditions de la visite du président Tebboune en France «pas idoines» | Le360 Afrique
text:
«En toute sincérité, les conditions de cette visite ne sont pas idoines», a déclaré M. Attaf dans un entretien accordé mercredi soir à Atheer, la plateforme de la chaine qatarie Al Jazeera.
M. Attaf a énuméré les dossiers de la mémoire, la mobilité, la coopération économique, les essais nucléaires français dans le Sahara algérien et celui de la restitution de l’épée ainsi que le burnous de l’émir Abdelkader.
Alors même que «le président devait se rendre au Château d’Amboise où était emprisonné l’Émir Abdelkader (...) les autorités françaises ont refusé (de restituer l’épée et le burnous de l’Emir) arguant la nécessité d’une loi» , a indiqué le ministre.
Concernant les essais nucléaires français, M. Attaf a indiqué que l’Algérie demandait «une reconnaissance des dommages causés» ainsi que «des indemnisations».
Lire aussi : Algérie: le patron de l’armée en visite officielle en France pour préparer celle de Tebboune
Entre 1960 et 1966, la France a procédé à 17 essais nucléaires sur les sites de Reggane, puis d’In Ekker, dans le Sahara algérien.
De documents déclassifiés en 2013 ont révélé des retombées radioactives importantes qui s’étendaient de l’Afrique de l’Ouest au sud de l’Europe.
«Nous ne sommes pas parvenus à des accords sur cinq grands et lourds dossiers. Mais nous continuons à travailler dessus», a réitéré le ministre en soulignant que les visites entre les responsables des deux pays se poursuivent pour préparer cette visite d’Etat.
Lire aussi : "Seuls les visas intéressent l'Algérie dans la relation avec la France", selon l'ex-ambassadeur de Paris à Alger
Début août, le président algérien Abdelmadjid Tebboune avait déclaré que sa visite d’Etat en France était «toujours maintenue» mais dépendait «du programme» de l’Élysée, précisant qu’une «visite d’État a des conditions» et «n’est pas une visite touristique» .
La visite, programmée d’abord début mai, avait été repoussée à juin, les Algériens craignant qu’elle ne soit gâchée par les manifestations du 1er mai contre la très contestée réforme des retraites en France, selon des sources concordantes.
Cette visite devait consacrer l’embellie entre les deux pays après de nombreuses crises diplomatiques.
 28/12/2023 à 19h49

author: Ron Hilliard
title: Northern lights to put on show, brief warmup headed to Metro Detroit this weekend
text: Under mostly clear to partly cloudy skies, temperatures will gradually fall into the 50s during the evening. This will mean great sky conditions for the chance of seeing the northern lights. Northern Lights A G4 geomagnetic storm watch is in effect for Thursday and Friday, which makes it the strongest since May. In areas away from city light pollution, the best chance to see the northern lights will be from 8 p.m. to midnight. The solar storm could stress “power grids already weakened by the hurricanes,” according to the Space Weather Prediction Center. The remnants of Milton will continue to move away from the U.S. over the Atlantic. Overnight lows will be in the lower to mid 40s in Southeast Michigan. The cooler temperatures will be near Ann Arbor, Howell, and Lapeer. Friday Friday will be partly cloudy with the return of warm weather. Afternoon temperatures will top out in the mid 70s, which is around 10 degrees above average. A fire weather watch will be in effect for Sanilac County in Southeast Michigan from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. on Friday. The watch will also cover the Saginaw Bay region and Northern Michigan. Dry, warm weather with gusty winds will elevate the fire risk. Winds will be out of the southwest at 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph over the Thumb. Nighttime temperatures will be in the upper 40s to lower 50s. Saturday Cooler air will flow into Metro Detroit on Saturday behind a cold front. A couple of showers will be possible, especially at night. Highs will be in the mid-60s, and lows will be in the mid-40s to 50 degrees. Sunday Sunday will bring a better chance of rain showers. Highs will be in the lower to mid-60s. Lows will be around 40 degrees. Monday Then, cooler air will push into Southeast Michigan on Monday. With a chance of showers, highs will only be in the mid-50s, which is typical of late October and early November. Just search your app store under WDIV and it’s right there available for both iPhones and Androids! Or click the appropriate link below.

author: Gene Frenette
title: Cruel for Jaguars' Fred Taylor to wait for HOF entry as long as Tony Boselli
text: If anybody can run into the Pro Football Hall of Fame using a different path than many already enshrined, it’s Fred Taylor . The legendary Jaguars running back made a monumental breakthrough Wednesday when he was announced as one of 15 modern-era finalists to get into Canton, clearing a hurdle that took him nine attempts to get over since first becoming eligible in 2016. Being a first-time finalist is a critical step for Taylor because it means his case will be presented before the 50 HOF voters at a mid-January meeting in Atlanta. Players elected will be secretly informed with a knock on their door in late January, then be introduced for the first time at the NFL Honors program on February 8. Sam Kouvaris , the former WJXT-Channel 4 sports director for 37 years and Jacksonville’s media representative on the HOF selection committee, will try to convince his voting colleagues that Taylor belongs in Canton despite lacking important accolades of many other candidates. Taylor has only one Pro Bowl on his resume, never made an All-Decade team or played in a Super Bowl. Seventy-five percent of those enshrined were All-Decade members and 64 percent won championships, according to HOF voter and stats guru Rick Gosselin , a Dallas-based NFL writer. “If you’re not All-Decade or haven’t won a championship, it’s a tough sell [to voters],” Gosselin said. Still, that doesn’t mean Taylor won’t gain entry. What he does have going for him is being 17th on the all-time rushing list with 11,695 yards, a robust 4.6-yard average per carry and the only back in history besides Barry Sanders and Adrian Peterson to have at least 2,500 carries and a 4.5-yard average. Of the 16 backs with more rushing yards than Taylor, 14 are in the Hall of Fame and the other two, Peterson and Frank Gore, will likely be enshrined when they become eligible. Kouvaris believes it’s telling Taylor was the only back among four semifinalists ( Eddie George, Ricky Watters and Tiki Barber ) to reach the finals. He looks forward to presenting Taylor’s case for the first time. “There’s a level of the eye test of which guys selectors put in the Hall of Fame and I think that part works in Fred’s favor. He was the opposite of a mundane back,” said Kouvaris. “He had a level of magic that made things happen. “Every time Fred touched the football, there was a chance he was going to score. You can’t say that about every running back.” But since HOF selectors can only put a maximum five of the 15 finalists into Canton, many deserving players wait a decade or longer to be enshrined, if they get in at all. Tony Boselli , the only Jaguar with a gold jacket, waited 16 years to get into the Hall and was passed over five times as a finalist before his election in 2022. There’s no telling how the voters will view the case of Taylor, who will have to overcome playing in a small market and in an era when several Hall of Fame backs — Edgerrin James, Curtis Martin, Jerom e Bettis, Ladanian Tomlinson and Marshall Faulk — overshadowed him in terms of recognition. With Taylor being one of six first-time finalists, the challenge for Kouvaris will be presenting a case to make the Jaguars’ legend (1998-2008) stand out against stiff competition from the likes of tight end Antonio Gates , pass-rushers Dwight Freeney , Jared Allen and Julius Peppers , along with a trio of receivers in Reggie Wayne, Torry Holt and Andre Johnson that have been finalists multiple times. “To sit in front of all those people and lay out why Fred separates himself from the everyday back, it’ll be exciting,” said Kouvaris. “It’s not just the presentation, but what the other selectors have to say about it. That can create momentum, maybe hear things they haven’t heard before about Fred. It’s a very important step.” Taylor belongs in the Hall of Fame, but so do most of the 14 other modern-era candidates. It’s a crapshoot trying to guess when or if the voters will put him in Canton. Boselli went through a brutally agonizing wait. Hopefully, Fred Taylor won’t have to endure the same thing. Except for offensive tackle Anton Harrison , who has lived up to his first-round draft status, the Jaguars’ 2023 draft class that featured 13 selections has yet to deliver much production. Tight end and second-round pick Brenton Strange has been on the field 33 percent of the time (265 snaps), but has only four catches for 34 yards. While he’s a serviceable blocker, a tight end taken that high must contribute more in the passing game. Running back Tank Bigsby , a third-round choice, had some fumbling issues midway through the season and has been limited to six snaps the past four games. Fourth-round linebacker Ventrell Miller , the most controversial of GM Trent Baalke ’s picks due to his injury history at Florida, has been on injured reserve all year. Defensive tackle Tyler Lacy shows some promise with 11 tackles (two for a loss) in 115 snaps. Undersized pass-rusher Yassir Abdullah got minimal playing time early and has been inactive the past 10 games. Antonio Johnson , a fifth-round selection, could turn out to be a steal and a future starter at safety. He has 63 snaps in the last three games, including a sack, forced fumble and a pass defense in the 31-27 loss to the Cleveland Browns. Receiver Parker Washington , though he has a couple touchdown among his 14 catches, remains a work in progress and must show more consistency. There’s still time for the 2023 draft class to ascend, but so far, Baalke hasn’t gotten the desired value from such a high volume of picks. More Gene Frenette: Jaguars bottom out against Buccaneers despite staying on top of AFC South Without 12 starters who have either declared for the NFL Draft, opted out to transfer or are injured, Florida State football has a monumental task as a 19.5-point underdog of trying to knock off Georgia in the Orange Bowl with third-teamer Brock Glenn playing quarterback. But the future of the program under Mike Norvell could be impacted far more by what possibly happens in a courtroom, not on the field. FSU and the ACC are locked in a legal battle over a grant-of-rights agreement signed in 2016 that might well end with the Seminoles leaving the ACC, depending on whether it can win a legal battle to reduce a $572 million exit fee. While FSU is suing the ACC to get out of the GOR, the league had already prepared its own lawsuit against one of its biggest brand members to force the Seminoles to honor the agreement. FSU has made no secret it wants out of the ACC because of the growing revenue gap compared to the Big Ten and SEC, the two most powerful leagues in college football. But even if FSU becomes a free agent, which could spur more realignment to destabilize the sport, there remains the unknown of whether the Big Ten (maybe) or SEC (probably not) would even want the Seminoles as a member. The only other viable option is the Big 12, and there’s no guarantee FSU would be happy with the revenue streams available there with Texas and Oklahoma bound for the SEC. The ramifications either way are enormous. If FSU winds up in the Big Ten, which triggered the demise of the Pac-12 Conference by swiping USC and UCLA, it might compel Clemson, North Carolina or Virginia to follow suit and break up the ACC. This ordeal figures to get messy. No matter the legal fallout, it’s hard to imagine FSU and the ACC sustaining a working relationship. A settlement agreement on the exit fee could happen. Then it becomes a question of where the ‘Noles can go, who might follow them and the ripple effects on the sport. Stay tuned. FSU (13-0) still has a chance to finish as the nation’s only unbeaten Power 5 team if either Texas or Alabama win the national championship. But if FSU manages to break away from the ACC by winning its lawsuit, that will shake up the college football world a lot more than taking down Georgia. When University of North Florida basketball coach Matthew Driscoll predicted in preseason that his “Birds of Trey” might attempt 40 three-point shots per game, it seemed like a far-fetched number. Well, the Ospreys have taken his message to heart by letting it fly liberally from long distance. UNF leads the nation in three-point shots made (175) and attempted (498), which translates into 35.6 attempts beyond the arc per game. Chaz Lanier , the team’s leading scorer at 16.1 points per game, is shooting an impressive .429 (45 of 105) on three-pointers. … The Denver Broncos’ benching of Russell Wilson for the team’s last two games while it’s still in playoff contention could have negative implications for his Hall of Fame quest. Wilson, a nine-time Pro Bowler and Super Bowl champion during his prime years with the Seattle Seahawks, is 18th on the all-time passing list (43,653 yards) and has a credible 334-106 TD-interception ratio. But if his two-year disappointing run in Denver is over, then the 35-year-old Wilson may need a good closing act somewhere else to solidify his HOF case. His current resume, which includes a 115-72-1 record as a starter, would be a tough call for voters. … Jacksonville Jaguars over Carolina Panthers by 4 (panic antidotes); Houston Texans over Tennessee Titans by 1 (playoff savior); Las Vegas Raiders over Indianapolis Colts by 3 (Jaguars thank-you cards); Kansas City Chiefs over Cincinnati Bengals by 4 (hangover remedies); Tampa Bay Buccaneers over New Orleans Saints by 3 (NFC South banners); Alabama over Michigan by 3 (cheater manuals); Texas over Washington by 6 (Pac-12 farewells). Last week: 1 right, 6 Los Angeles Dodgers money pits. Gfrenette@jacksonville.com : (904) 359-4540; Follow him on X, formerly Twitter, at @genefrenette

author: T13
title: Emiten alerta máxima por tormenta solar | T13
text: El Centro de Predicción del Clima Espacial de la NOAA (Oficina Nacional de Administración Oceánica y Atmosférica) emitió una alerta de tormenta geomagnética severa (G4), tormenta solar. Fueron vistas al menos cinco eyecciones de masa coronal (CME) acercándose a la Tierra y se espera que lleguen alrededor del mediodía de este viernes 10 de mayo hasta el domingo 12. Asimismo, se han observado varias llamaradas fuertes en los últimos días, asociadas con una mancha solar grande, que tiene 16 veces el diámetro de la [Tierra](https://www.t13.cl/etiqueta/planeta-tierra), por lo que se espera actividad solar adicional. En la historia, solo se han observado tres tormentas geomagnéticas severas. El último G4 (grave) fue en marzo de 2024 y el último G5 (extremo) en el 2003. Según explicó la meteoróloga Michelle Adam a “Tu Día”, en octubre del 2003 se registraron cortes de energías y daños de transformadores a nivel mundial. A más de 20 años, se teme que la tormenta solar podría dañar satélites considerando que somos seres humanos más conectados. Hay más celulares y por lo tanto, más satélites. [ Lee También ](/noticia/mundo/rusia-no-se-detiene-lanza-nueva-ofensiva-terrestre-ucrania-10-5-2024) Rusia no se detiene y lanza nueva ofensiva terrestre en Ucrania “Frente a una situación como esta, se tiene que tener en consideración que pueden fallar las conexiones del teléfono e internet”, aseguró la meteoróloga. Por otra parte, este fenómeno podría provocar una mayor cantidad de auroras boreales con mayores posibilidades de ser vistas en el norte de Estados Unidos, Canadá y el norte de Europa. [Síguenos en ](https://news.google.com/publications/CAAiEOgjh55R1O_OHSPw0T00iXYqFAgKIhDoI4eeUdTvzh0j8NE9NIl2)

author: Applied Intuition, Inc.
title: Applied Intuition Announces Favorable Resolution of Securities Complaint
text:
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. , Dec. 28, 2023 /PRNewswire/ -- As previously disclosed, on May 25, 2023 , Embark Technology, Inc. ("Embark") and Applied Intuition, Inc. ("Applied") entered into an Agreement and Plan of Merger, pursuant to which, among other matters, Azara Merger Sub, Inc. merged with and into Embark, with Embark continuing as the surviving corporation and as a wholly owned subsidiary of Applied (the "Merger").
On June 26, 2023 , a putative class action complaint was filed in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware ("Court") by Marceil A. Hanshew , a stockholder of Embark ("Plaintiff"), against Embark and the then-members of Embark's Board of Directors (collectively, "Defendants"), captioned Marceil A. Hanshew v. Embark Technology, Inc. et al. , C.A. No. 2023-0654-NAC (the "Action"). The complaint alleged that the disclosures made in the preliminary proxy statement on Schedule 14A filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC") on June 16, 2023 , in connection with the Merger, contained false and misleading statements. The complaint sought, among other forms of relief, a preliminary injunction to enjoin the Merger.
On June 26, 2023 , Embark filed a definitive proxy statement on Schedule 14A with the SEC ("Proxy"), and on June 29, 2023 , Plaintiff and Plaintiff's spouse, David L. Hanshew (collectively, "Plaintiffs"), filed an amended complaint captioned David L. Hanshew in His Capacity as Attorney-in-Fact for Marceil A. Hanshew and Marceil A. Hanshew v. Embark Technology, Inc. et al. , C.A. No. 2023-0654-NAC.
To resolve the Action, Plaintiffs and Defendants ultimately agreed that Embark would make certain additional disclosures, which Embark made in Amendment No. 1 to the Proxy filed with the SEC on July 10, 2023 (the " July 10 Amendment").
On August 1, 2023 , Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the Action as moot, and later that day, the Court entered a stipulated order dismissing the Action with prejudice as to the Plaintiffs and without prejudice as to any actual or potential claims of any other member(s) of the putative class. The Court retained jurisdiction solely for the purpose of adjudicating Plaintiffs' counsel's anticipated application for an award of attorneys' fees and reimbursement of expenses in connection with the disclosures in the July 10 Amendment.
In order to avoid the time and expense of continued litigation, Applied, as successor in interest of Embark, subsequently agreed to pay $114,000 to Plaintiffs' counsel for attorneys' fees and expenses in full satisfaction of their claim for attorneys' fees and expenses in the Action. On December 21, 2023 , the Court entered an order closing the case, subject to Applied filing an affidavit with the Court confirming that this notice has been issued. In entering the order, the Court was not asked to review, and did not pass judgment on, the payment of the attorneys' fees and expenses or their reasonableness.
SOURCE Applied Intuition, Inc.
